Erik's pulley was designed for 5 mm pitch belt, but the only belts I could find have 0.2 inch pitch.  This is close enough to almost work, but the belt slips sometimes.  The diameter and pitch of this part has been modified to work better with 0.2 inch belts.
Note:  This was a really easy change if you have OpenSCAD installed.  I'm uploading it for anyone who just wants to grab the .stl file.
Replaces the z-driven-pulley and two z-driven-rims.

I have had this pair of knuckles designed for some time. I have since wanted to make a carabiner combination. Now is the time that they collide for more form than function.
Functioning knuckles? Sure, although you might hurt yourself.
Functioning carabiner? Absolutely, but you may get stopped on the street for wearing one.
Win win. Carabiner mechanism thanks to Jinja. I credit the name of this thing to Jeremy Gonzalez's quick wit.

This scale fits my on-the-small-side-man-hands. Scale it up or down to fit. Jinja's mechanism works like a dream so no problems there. This print seems solid at 10% infill. Increase to get a longer life span out of the part. I offer 3 sizes for ease of scaling.
Fila-buster has a ring size of about 11/12 or about 20mm diamter
Fila-buster_med has a ring size of about 15/16 or about 24mm diameter
Fila-buster_lrg has a ring size of about 21/22 or about 29mm diameter The photo is from Steve Gonzalez, he wanted something to hook onto his gym bag, so he scaled the original file to 1.557 the size. Quite large compared to the original.

This is a very simple, inexpensive and yet effective dry bag for filament.

Parts required for the build: One Ziploc Big Bag Large size
One 50 gram pack of orange indicating desiccant Tools required Phillips #0 screw driver Assembly Poke holes in the desiccant pack with a Phillips #0 screw driver. I suggest six to eight holes spread evenly over the top of the pack. Place spools in Ziploc bag and place desiccant pack on top, seal bag. I find over night in a heated place is enough to dry out PLA to be printable again. When beads in the pack turn green it is time to think about replacing it or refreshing it in the oven. Amazon link for Ziploc: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003U6A3C6/ref=oh_details_o00_s00_i00
eBay link for desiccant: http://offer.ebay.com/ws/eBayISAPI.dll?BinConfirm&_trksid=p2047675.l1356&rev=4&item=221056467788 Suggested warm place: top of your hot water tank. (if your hot water tank isn't water tight you've got bigger issues than damp PLA) Update 12/27/2012: I have now tested this design using an Eva-dry Renewable EDV-300/E-333 Wireless Mini Dehumidifer. This device has a built in dryness indicator so you know when your filament is staying dry and when you need to renew the dehumidifier. The device has a built in drier that allows you to plug it into the wall over night and have it dry itself out. Device is rated to absorb up to a cup of water. The Ziplock Big Bag and Eva Dry can both be purchased from Amazon. http://www.amazon.com/Eva-dry-Renewable-E-333-Wireless-Dehumidifer/dp/B000H0XFCS/ref=cm_cmu_up_thanks_hdr

Some of the color changing ones are toxic.

comments.author: talpa

comments.text: Exactly, that's why I've been using and recommend the orange stuff from the person in Singapore. At this point though I am highly impressed with the Eva Dry. The bags are .4 cubic feet when fully expanded and generally I push most of the air out so they're really more like .2 cubic feet. The Eva Dry is rated for many times that volume and it shows in drying times. I don't have to leave filament in over night with the Eva Dry to tune it back up. I can pop it in for an hour and get a nice razor clean print from it.

description.text: I needed to reduce the internal diameter of my fish pond pump outflow port from 22 mm to 12 mm to suit the existing hose setup so I designed this reducing fitting.  You can change the diameters in the OpenSCAD to suit your own installation.  My first OpenSCAD to STL project :-)

Printed on a Replicator 1 using 1.70 mm ABS at 100% infill (watertight ...) with 0.2 mm layer thickness and 50 mm/s feed rate.  Use a raft and print with the larger diameter sitting flush with the build plate.

comments.text: Usually on pumps, more stress is added when the bore is fully open as then the pump will shift more fluid. As long as there is enough flow to cool the pump, then a smaller bore means a smaller load.

comments.text: This is neat, but it will put more stress on your pump, reducing it's life and maximum head, but if those don't matter, it's perfect!

Who wants to mess with cutters and cardboard when you have a 3D printer. This case is designed to take a lens (from a dollar store binocular).
The lens had a focal length of 75mm.
The holes fit 38mm lens from a cheap dollor store binocular, I used the mount from the binocular itself, just yanked it out so it fits snugly in the holes.
This is more for a concept as its unlikely you will find the same binocular or have a Nexus 5 in the exact same case as I do.
Kids had a lot of fun.
Print, drop lenses on one end, the phone on the other. Enjoy.

title: Poor Mans Quick Change Spindle For 1 lb Plastic

description.text:
This was my answer to the need for a quick change spool for 1 lb coils of plastic. I like to frequently switch between colors. This spool lets me slip off the old coil and slip on a new coil. Its worked well with a 2+ hour print.
It really needs a larger bottom disk since the 1 lb coils tend to unwind. The largest round cake board my wife had was 16 inch, I think 20 inch might be enough.

buy cheapo $20, 10 inch round turn table (lazy susan) from WalMart.
--- top needs to be no larger than 10 inch for easy slip on and slip off of coils glue three pegs into base (mine kept falling out). Do not glue the top on so it can be removed if necessary when changing coils. 20 inch round piece of card board ( I only had 16 inch ) punch holes for pegs in round cardboard. place cardboard on pegs. load coil of plastic. print away NOTE: I velcroed some of the plastic coil since my round cardboard was a little too small.

This chair was created using the Exquisite Corpse method of designing, concealing and passing it on to the next player for their contribution.  
Each player was only given the top slice of the previous design to work from. Their design had to utilize digital fabrication and the design files had to be open.
The three players were Ronen Kadushin, Jens Dyvik and Nick Graham. Designed from the bottom up, the chair was split into three parts. Legs, seat and back. 
This is the result.

For seatBack file:
CNC cut from 18mm timber/ply. 
For bracket3mmMildSteel file:
Get files laser cut from 3mm mild steel. You could go thinner. 3mm was just insurance that everything was going to remain in the same place. Once cut, fold the 4 longest folds first. Make sure that both brackets are mirrors of each other and not copies. Then fold the remaining folds away from the center of the bracket. Note each fold should be 90 degrees. Attach to the seat frame using an M10 x 90mm bolt and nut for each bracket. See images for reference. 
For seatPan12mmWood, seatFrame25mmWood, seatText3mmAcrylic files:
The CNC millied parts should be made from massive wood planks 25mm and 12mm thick, minimum width is 80mm and 100mm (see reference file). The dogbones are designed for a 6mm milling bit. The engraved text for the seat planks should be milled with a 6mm bit and 3mm deep. The depth of the different pockets are specified in the layer names.
You should be able to import the dxf directly to partworks with color coded named layers. Remember to join open vectors once you have imported.
The lasercut parts should be made from 3mm thick pink, purple or similar acrylic.
To assemble the seat to the legs you will need 8 x M10 90mm long bolts, plus nuts. There is 0mm tolerance on all the parts. I recommend a sharp single or doubleflute upcut milling bit.
For legsOak file:
Machine out of oak, on a CNC. These chair legs were inspired by designer Phil Cuttance and his faceture project.

title: Plate support for 2 Reprappro Mendel extruders for Enlarged Rostock

description.text: This is a plate for mounting 2 Reprappro Mendel extruders on Enlarged Rostok. The logic of this is one direction freedom for easy tuning/adjustment of alignment on Z, and Y.

The heat sinks must be drilled and tapped. I chose to do it on the median line of upper rectangular face of heat sink. I tapped the holes for M3. One extruder is mounted with springs between plate and heat sink through fixed tapped holes. This can be adjusted on Z, and its position is the reference for the other extruder on Y position. The next extruder is mounted through elongated holes with washers between plate and heat sink, and its position is the reference for the other extruder on Z position. There are three screws mounted from the lower face of the plate through, and screwed with M3 nuts, which are used for mounting the plate from underneath to the efector platform.

title: Support for MG90S servo mounted on Reprappro Mendel extruder for auto bed leveling

description.text: This is a support for MG90S servo with a very smart stable arm see this very intelligent design http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:335203 mounted on Reprappro Menedel extruder. The purpose of it is auto bed leveling. I found out that the stability of servo's arm is critical for auto bed leveling. All other designs of servo's arm failed to be very reliable from the point of view of stability, but this one due to the mechanical stop (in construction of) assures I would say 100% stability and repeatability. Thank you Ralf for your design.

The support is sandwiched between the fan and heat sink. The original design of the arm has a limited range of movement, and due to this I extended the profile hole on the primary arm in order to increase the range of movement from 30 degrees to 120 degrees. I did this modification by grinding the hole but as Ralf provided IGS file you can adjust it as you wish.

title: Solarium Part, test your support settings.

description.text:
This is a replacement part that was broken on a solar room cover.  I posted it to show how my support settings are working.  Since most of the object is actually flat in the air, almost the entire object is on support.  IT WORKS GREAT.  When you are finished printing, the raft support just pulls right off with an accordian effect.
Since I had not seen this, I posted the gcode and my raft/support settings.  This was printed without a raft.
you may want to scale this down, as it uses a lot of plastic.  But if you want to try my support settings, you will see its great.

comments.text: Raft has two layers, the first horizontal layer print, the second vertical layer. The second layer is what gets extended upward for support when support is turned on.

comments.author: jstiltner

comments.text:
I screwed around with support settings in skeinforge. (under Raft). The settings are in the CSV file below.
basically, base layers 0, infill density .4, interface layers 0, support material everywhere turned off (false), degrees 60. But see CSV. You then need to select "print raft" if you are running skeinforge from within replicator. The trick is to get the support material printing in only one direction, re x or y, but not both, and to have enough space between them but not too much, in my opinion.

author: neoteric

description.text:
Here is a bearing that uses truncated elliptical rollers instead of balls. This is intended to be easy to print all as one print without having to try to break the bearings free. Theoretically it should just come off of the build platform working with no cleanup. This is the first thing I have made in openscad, as I just started learning it today in preparation for my printerâ€™s arrival. Also I don't have my printer yet so don't know if it prints properly. Please try it out and let me know!
Update 1.1 (FIX): Still truncated elliptical rollers. Scaling fix so that roller ends are at same z level as ring edges (they were slightly off in the original version due to a 0.95 z scaling factor that I missed). I'm not sure if it is enough of a difference to mess up printing but I figured I'd fix it anyway. Also width changed to 21mm for closer roller packing. 
Update 2.0: New roller profile! Now has a tiered or crowned roller profile to prevent x and y rotation of rollers. I realized that there was a possibility of unintentional x or y rotation with the truncated elliptical rollers from version 1.
Update 2.1: Slightly larger rollers to reduce play and also much tighter roller packing. Same profile as 2.0

Update 1.1 (FIX): Still truncated elliptical rollers. Scaling fix so that roller ends are at same z level as ring edges (they were slightly off in the original version due to a 0.95 z scaling factor that I missed). I'm not sure if it is enough of a difference to mess up printing but I figured I'd fix it anyway. Also width changed to 21mm for closer roller packing. Update 2.0: New roller profile! Now has a tiered or crowned roller profile to prevent x and y rotation of rollers. I realized that there was a possibility of unintentional x or y rotation with the truncated elliptical rollers from version 1. Update 2.1: Slightly larger rollers to reduce play and also much tighter roller packing. Same profile as 2.0 I tried to design is so it would just print all at once and come off the platform working without cleanup. The things that may be problematic are: rollers breaking free from platform during print, too small of a gap between rollers and inner and outer ring, you may need to reposition the print so that it is not partially below the build platform (there are negative z values in the model, I don't know if this is a problem), inner ring or rollers falling out, the geometry may be too dense as well (as I donâ€™t know what kind of resolution is required to get good prints), there's probably something I don't know about yet. Dimensions:
Outer radius: 50mm (total 100mm across)
Inner radius: 25mm (total 50mm across)
Thickness: 20mm (21mm for V1.1) I've attached my openscad file as well so you guys can use it or change it or fix my mistakes. I was trying to make it somewhat parametric but couldn't get the roller number to scale appropriately. The two driving dimensions are the outer radius for the two rings and the thickness for the roller size. The number of rollers will have to be changed manually (in the last statement) if the outer radius to thickness ratio changes. I also added a sketchup file so you can easily see the shape and design of the rollers / channel.

description.text:
" Simplicity is the ultimate sophistication " Leonardo Da Vinci The following project has being developed as a proof of concept for a new generation of high speed transportation vehicles All areas that could affect it in reality had being addressed, making it not just another nice electronic model with a number of renders but a viable product in years to come The final STL model its made of a number of components which are to be assembled, therefore giving the opportunity of manufacturing it in a variety of colors according to the different parts While this model has being finished, new improvements will be made such as the manufacturing of the interiors and more detailed parts and components Sincerely Miguel Riego S Resume During the next 20 years, many new forms of transportation will come into our lives, some of them will be geared towards resolving the issue of fuel consumption.for example Electrical vehicles are here to stay and will become major players in the years to come New highly advanced intelligent systems will let our vehicles be autonomous, taking the necessary decisions to make our travel and use safe and comfortable. However the thrill of traveling will not be lost with dull and passive products
This is a proposal based on and intelligent highway induction system called Alfa 2040 The vehicle will be a Land Crusier capable of achieving 300 KM per Hour and will be stabilized by state of the art gyroscopic systems, taking the necessary energy from the road. Therefore eliminating the need to recharge It will be lightweight using intelligent Nano materials that will be able to change and morph as needed making the unit for example more aerodynamic by changing the composition of its body to replicate the one found on the skin of sharks, Self-glow will be another feature in order to be able to be seeing at night or in bad weather conditions VEHICLE SPECS Powetrain Power Phase Select 145 â€¢ 400 Nm peak torque
â€¢ 145 kW peak, 85 kW continuous motor power
â€¢ 145 kW peak, 85 kW continuous generator power
â€¢ Full Power at 340-420 VDC
â€¢ Microprocessor-controlled inverter with sine wave drive
â€¢ Application-friendly graphical user interface
â€¢ System efficiencies of up to 92.5 percent Drive by wire multi directional magnetic technology 5 AXIS Body: Single monocoque construction based on intelligent Nano materials (Self adaptive) Manufacturing method for body components Advanced Nano Tech Fusion Deposit Manufacturing (FDM) Thanks to breakthroughs in nano materials, materials composed of incredibly tiny structures that are engineered at a scale of 1 to 100 nanometers. (To understand the scale we're talking about, imagine putting three to five atoms in a line. That would be one nanometer.) By moving atoms around, scientists can fashion materials that are incredibly strong yet light, and have other special abilities as well. Some production cars, such as the Chevy Cobalt and the BMW M6, already have carbon nano fiber parts, but car makers could go a lot further. As EV World reported last December, researchers at Germany's [/url="http://tu-dresden.de/en"]Technical University of Dresden[/url] unveiled an experimental single-seat racing car, the E-Wolf e1, designed to show how light a car can be. The E-Wolf is made mostly from carbon nano fiber, which is five times as strong as steel but just a fraction of the weight. The vehicle weighs just 990 pounds (449 kilograms), and most of that weight is batteries (the body panels, frame, interior and other parts come in at just under 400 pounds/181.4 kilograms). LAYOUT 2 Passenger configuration

This project is part of the Grabcad/ makerbot Challenge
http://grabcad.com/library/energy-induced-intelligent-vehicle
Data will be released as soon as it becomes avialable in stl format.to construct this product
The vehicle here shown and its components have being designed accordingly with the standards and steps used at major automotive and transportation firms.
A high degree of detail is being acheived as well as class A surfaces. Therefore it will be an interesting challenge for any user with and FDM or STL manufacturing capabilities
If you will like to have fuirther infromation please contact me at [email protected]

Important notice! There is a slight flaw with the earlier design which causes the J-Head to wobble during print causing prints to have uneven surfaces. I have upload the revised .scad file and removed the previous design. I made a J-head adapter for my Printrbot Simple All-metal so that I can try out the J-head series of hotends and in case my stock UBIS hotend burns out. I found out the J-head I have is about 10 mm too short and due to the Z-axis almost touching the minimum height, I decided to make an attachment to extend the hotend further downwards.
Currently the OpenScad file is a little messy but I will work on making it user friendly with comments explaining the use of each parameters. Also, the current parameters made the J-head hotend longer by about 10 mm compared to the UBIS hotend. This extension cause the fan to be blow towards the PEEK insulator instead of the nozzle end which is good in cooling the PLA part but bad during printing.
Next few changes would be to:
1) Shorten the adapter so the length is comparable to the UBIS hotend.
2) Add fins to the surface to improve surface heat dissipation.
3) Add a mount for a fan to keep the PLA printed part from deforming or worst, melt.
If you need a specific size in .stl, please do send me a comment anytime and I will try my best to upload it as soon as possible .

Layer resolution: 0.1 mm
Fill: 60%
Support everywhere & Brim turned on.
Additional stuff, 2pcs 12 mm long M3 Hex screws and nuts.

author: ImoraB

description.text:
I re placed My Apple TV and 3d Printer computer with a 2006 Mac Mini. To try to keep my work bench Clear, I made another wall mount. The other bonus is the increase air flow around the computer.
I added a Fan Mount to the bottom. It's a 70mm x 15mm 12vdc fan. First I zip tide it to the mount, and then I couldn't stand the look of it. So I added the mount and now have a great way to aline the mount.
The fan screen was made, because my fingers keep getting clipped.
I printed this at a 15%fill and 3 walls. All Screws are #8 size, fine machine to put the pieces together and tapered head wood screws.You will need 4 wood screws and 6x2inch fine machine screws.

comments.text: Have printed this.  I have to admit, I was a little confused with the lack of detail, so I'll fill in a bit here.  The two large bracket shaped pieces are actually only ONE SIDE of the mount.  In other words you must print TWO EACH of the large pieces.  The brackets go together such that the one thicker piece has its upright to the wall and it is what bears the weight of the Mac Mini.  The thinner piece is screwed to the side of the thick piece and forms the OPPOSITE side (front) of the bracket.  So your Mac Mini slides down between the two uprights.  Pretty good, actually, because it leaves plenty of room for air movement.  As the instructions say, 6 #8 fine machine thread screws are good.  Two inches is longer than you really need; 1.5 inches would be plenty of length.  With two inch screws, you get 1/2 inch hanging out on the inside.  Not a bad thing, just not critical.  Although with a 2 inch screw you'll have plenty of thread to throw a matching nut on the innermost one for security.  The fan bracket pieces get attached to the inside of each bracket to hold the fan.  I found one on Amazon, plus bought a 3 pin to USB adapter so the Mac Mini can power the fan directly.  Anyway, just wanted to leave some clarification for any numpties like me who couldn't figure out how to put it all together.  Great design, very strong even at 15% infill, and saved me a ton of design time.  Cheers!

title: Vertical dial indicator support for graber i3 carriage

description.text: There are just too many supports for dial indicators which use a horizontal carriage (like the one from prusa i3) but seemingly none which takes advantage of a vertically oriented carriage. Therefore, I just made one. Enjoy.

Print with support.
Take the support off.
Fit the dial indicator into the groove.
Fix it with a M5 bolt and nut.
Fit the piece into the graber i3 X carriage and take the measurements you want. The piece should be a tight fit but it should also be able to slide in the carriage.
I printed mine with 0.2mm layer height and 40% infill, but it should work with any other settings.

description.text:
Blender has a cloth modeling system that can realistically animate planes as though they were different kinds of cloth. A fun trick I've found is putting different things between a cloth object and the floor and then printing the result of it falling for a few dozen frames. Provided you can either get your slicer to infer that the "inside" is what's under the dome or just extrude plastic along the perimeter, these will print readily. I've included the .blend file, but be sure to check out the excellent BlenderCookie tutorial for more details on using the cloth simulator:
http://www.blendercookie.com/2010/08/17/cloth-simulation/ Note: I think if you used Blender's "solidify" modifier you could get them in shape enough to take 'em to Shapeways...

These days I hesitate to say something will only slice with SuperSkein, but I sure had better luck than I would have expected out of SkeinForge, so here's a link to the GitHub repository where you can download the source: http://github.com/MaskedRetriever/SuperSkein/archives/master And a standalone application: http://github.com/MaskedRetriever/SuperSkein/downloads

description.text: Many of us have been frustrated to discover that the pins for emmett's Screwless Heart Gears are not PLA compatible. They are too stiff, and in my experience, attempting to force them in can crack the pins and damage the piece itself. So I set about trying to design some alternative pins for PLA. My first attempt was to make flexible end tabs, but while this worked, the gear heart axle is too short to support this approach. In the next attempt, I altered the internal structure of the tip of the pin to make it more flexible for PLA and redesigned the protrusions. These new pins were designed using an ACIS solid in Shark FX (sfx file included) so will behave well with Makerware, ReplicatorG and skeinforge. They snap into place with moderate force and rotate freely. UPDATE Version 2 of the pins has 0.25 mm more protrusion on each side at the tip, they still insert with moderate force but have a firmer hold.

PINS ONLY If you have already made Emmett's Screwless Heart Gears, then these pins are a drop in replacement. Simply download and print PLA-gear-heart-pins.stl file - that's all you need. If you are using Makerware I would recommend at least a 0.2mm layer height, 3 shells and 15% infill. In ReplicatorG I am doing the same, but using the skin module to achieve a 0.1 mm outer surface finish. HEART GEAR PLATES If you want to make the PLA heart gears from scratch, simply download and print the two plates: PLA-gear-heart-plate1.stl and PLA-gear-heart-plate2.stl. The first plate includes my snap off ear raft print aids, to increase the surface area of the small gears to prevent them from breaking loose during printing. Again, if you are using Makerware I would recommend at least a 0.2mm layer height, 3 shells and 15% infill. In ReplicatorG I am doing the same, but using the skin module to achieve a 0.1 mm outer surface finish.

comments.text: Hi, I don't know if your experiencing the same problem that I had, but in my case the printer nozzle was pushing my build plate ever so slightly down (no matter how I calibrated it if it was to high it wouldn't adhere, and the slight adjustment between the two still slightly pushed the build platform down). I ended up putting 3d printed supports between the build plate and the frame work of my makerbot rep 2. Curling problems have been significantly reduced and I can still calibrate my build platform even with them in. Hope this helps.

title: {[Fast Print]} Fillament Spool Holder with 608zz and M8 rod

description.text:
Fillament Spool Holder with 608zz and M8 rod.
This should be a easy and fast print! Printed mine
@45mm/s, 10% infill.
50mm ?, 10,5mm highest point.
One is for 39mm spool, the other (marked) is for 30mm spool.
I hope it can be useful for someone. Please comment!
Parts needed:
1pcs Threaded Rod M8 150mm (Length optional)
2pcs Threaded Rod M8 130mm (length optional, for use with Rod-M8 angles like the picture)
2pcs 608zz Bearing
2pcs M8 lock nut
2pcs M8 nut
2pcs M8 washer
Print two pcs of this "thing" and two Rod-m8 angles (one mirrored for estetic :) ).
Place bearing into middle of both "holders" and put the rod thru and lock it into place.
I am going to use this on my custom build. Bore a hole in chassi and run the threaded rod thru. Locking it in place with two lock nuts and then the holders with ordinary nuts. So that the spool holder is placed on the back of my chassi.
But for now I am using it on my prusa i3 with m8 rod angles.
UPDATE 20140717: Bowden_M5 Fitting

title: Solar Charged Intelligent LED Bike Light

description.text: Here is a complete product project of endtas design. Alien Light Mini is a LED headlight for bicycles. It has got two 1W leds, one with a wide angle and the other with a narrow beam angle lens. The wide lens is a bit turned towards the ground to light up nearby ahead and the other straight ahead for greater distance lighting. Visit the free product design projects website www.endtas.com for circuit schematic, hex file and other details. There are other projects too.

This is a microprocessor controlled inttelligent light with 9 lighting modes.

  • Double 5mm led flash

  • Double 1W leds triple flash

  • Double 1W leds continuous flash

  • Continuous power 1st grade + flash/2seconds

  • Continuous power 2nd grade

  • Continuous power 3rd grade

  • Continuous power 4th grade

  • Continuous power 5th grade

  • SOS signal flash mode. Flashes S.O.S distress signal with 2 1W LEDs.
    • The light circuit is designed to work with two Nokia cell batteries but the prototype is made by using 3AAA type batteries, generating 3.6V aprox. The product can run for days at the minimum power setting and more than 3 hours at max power.

title: Wire Strain Relief for Printrbot Simple Metal Heat Bed Modification

description.text: A simple bolt-on wire strain relief for the Printrbot Simple Metal heat bed mod that will keep your wires from breaking.

I added a heated metal print bed to my Printrbot Simple Metal, following in_the_garage's instructions at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:329561. But after a few prints, my wire harness broke from all the twisting. So I designed and made this simple clip-on wire strain relief for the print bed. It attaches using two 12mm long M3 socket-head machine screws and M3 hex nuts. Add a wire tie and some wire loom and you're done!

The default RepRapPro Mendel method of mounting the extruder with three tab clips is pretty bad; it's very floppy, the front clip can't be pulled up on properly, and it mounts the motor low enough that you can't use the full height of the printer.
This part replaces the 2mm thick spacer and sits with four U-shaped feet on to both top bars, resulting in the motor being about 10mm higher.

• Buy some M3x16mm caps, washers and plain nuts
  • Separate the extruder drive from its motor
  • From the bottom of the two bolts that the filament enters between remve the washers. They stop the extruder drive from sitting flat
  • Discard the square 2mm thick spacer plate
  • Put nuts in each of the four feet, and use four bolts to temporarily hold them in place
  • Slide the motor in place
  • Remove the four bolts (the motor will now hold the nuts in place)
  • Turn over and place the extruder drive in top, and bolt through this part into the motor in the same way as the spacer plate you discarded
  • Place on the top bars
  • Put a bolt and washer through each of the four feet to secure. Tightening will pull the two prongs of the feet together, closing it up and preventing the assembly from lifting.

This is a shim for the pulleys that drive the Y axis on the Da vinci 1.0 3d printer. Nice and simple to install. Just snaps in place in between the pulley and snap ring on the three pulleys in the back of the machine. Make sure you install it on the side that does not have the black pin in the pulley. Using these will take backlash out of the belt drive system making your parts print better.

I printed this part in ABS at 100% fill. It should fit your machine. If not you may have to scale it in the z axis to make it thicker or thinner. If part is thick you can always rub it on sandpaper a little to make it fit better. Make sure you push the pulley toward the pin so this part has room to be installed. Install it on the side opposite of the pin so the pin is locked into the pulley and the pulley has no backlash on the shaft.

title: 26 Angels Ornament
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
In memory of Allison, Ana, Anne Marie, Avielle, Benjamin, Caroline, Catherine, Charlotte, Chase, Daniel, Dawn, Dylan, Emilie, Grace, Jack, James, Jesse, Jessica, Josephine, Lauren, Madeleine, Mary, Noah, Olivia, Rachel, and Victoria. 
Your tragic death just breaks my heart. :'(
Update: I uploaded all the working files, too. The svg contains versions with original objects (with original font, and font converted to curves), objects converted to curves, combined curves, and prepped for export. If you don't have the original font (Kristen ITC), then the first version in the SVG probably won't look good, but the others should look fine.)

Print. I put it up on Shapeways, too, in case anyone wants to buy one. There's no mark-up. http://www.shapeways.com/model/837613/26-angels-ornament.html To be clear: ^^^There should be no markup on the shapeways ornament. In other words, I'm not trying to profit at all from this tragedy---that's not how I roll. I added this to shapeways because a friend expressed interest in getting one in metal, and that's a material I cannot print. If you choose to order it on shapeways, then they will charge you to print it, like they do with everything they print, but I'm pretty sure I set it up properly when I used "+$0.00" for the markup.

comments.text: Not trying to come off the wrong way but selling them on shapeways is not really memorializing them its profiting. I don't see it as much of an issue if its free to download but to sell is different.

title: Parameterized Rectangular Holder / Stand (SCAD) v2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A fully parameterizable "stand" or "holder" for anything that will fit in a rectangular hole. I specifically used it to create a desktop stand for a cell phone, but as the pictures show, you could also use it to make a sugar packet holder or business card holder.
The size of the rectangular "hole", the wall thickness, the base size are all customizable via parameters. You can also decide if you want just the vertical corners rounded, or all (top/bottom) corners rounded.
The scad file also has a "test" mode that prints a 8mm high rectangular piece you can fit around your object to make sure it will fit into the "hole" once you print the full sized holder/stand.
Version 2: Includes a "viewing cutout" if you want to be able to see the screen of your cell phone.

If you just want a Motorola Backflip or Sony Xperia Mini cell phone holder, go ahead and slice and print the appropriate STL file. Otherwise, you'll need to use OpenSCAD to open the .scad file, edit the size of your holder/base/hole and optional viewing cutout and then generate your own STL file.

This is a coffee bean grinder.
It's essentially hand powered burr grinder with 1mm radius sized holes for coffee grounds to come out of.
It's a very simple job requires 3 prints, 2 3mm nuts and bolts and a glue gun for sealing.
Use it by putting beans in the top and turning the burr a lot, this process is tedious and needs some arm power.
** The photos are the original version of the grinder with less refinements but it's the same idea. Here's a video of it in action ! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LS-nceswKVQ&feature=youtu.be

Ok so after all the parts are printed you may need to drill out the grind holes depending on how your printer performs.
Insert the Centre Burr into to the cylinder. The outer burrs of the cylinder should be on the bottom of the device and it'll keep the inner burr that you spin inside the device. Next screw in and glue the base (the screws will help the glue from seperating)
If you really don't want to use any non 3d printed parts other than glue, apply glue then heat gun it to give it extra stick, thats what I did.
Job done!

description.text:
Update posted as separate thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:387134
This is my work in progress (perhaps excessively robust) delta printer design. Most parts are in version 1, although I've designed a little more than I've posted so far and have the majority of the construction sitting on my desk for development purposes. I will add to this post as I refine the design.
Note: the currently posted models are not intended for 3D printing (and half the parts are missing anyway!). These models have been bundled into blocks to be used in OpenSCAD for animation only. Once I'm happy with a sufficient number of the parts to actually make a printer to this design, I'll post individual files and instructions. The files posted are actually my inverse kinematics test for my unconventional delta printer joints in the form of an OpenSCAD animation.
I will add to this thing as I have working parts, so if interested, keep an eye out.
A near current state of development can be seen in https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Za5Z9-ACVQw As it turns out, I did have some plastic warp due to the heat from the stepper motors but was too drunk at the time of filming to notice! This issue has been (hopefully) solved.
Recent additions:
Clamps for a 280 mm diameter glass build plate using foldback clips and latch mechanism. This was developed to avoid having any plastic in contact with a bed that will ultimately be heated.
Pen holder to plot a test pattern. 10 mm came out damn close to 10 mm in both axes and across the build plate considering I've not carefully measured rod lengths or aligned my endstops yet! :D
To view model in OpenSCAD, download all files to the same folder on your computer and open the .scad file.

Jason

title: BIONICLE Nuva Cube + Symbols
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Nuva symbols held the power of the Toa Nuva, and also served as the keys to the prison of the Bahrag - the cube being the lock.
Who doesn't love bringing childhoods back?
BIONICLE lives on! EDIT 27/11: I found that the symbols were way too big, so I had to redesign them, or you guys will have a lot of sanding and filing to do. The symbols have been rescaled, so everything should be fine, since I personally printed them out to check.

Well, I took a veery roundabout way to do it...
The cube was simple enough, dividing the thing up into sections then reverse-extruding (subtracting) out of it to create the symbols on the cube. You might see a smaller cube within it, with the symbols a sort of 'cage around it, but really I started with the whole cube before anything.
The symbols were a whole lot harder. Since I was too lazy to do this in AutoCAD (which would have been a helluva LOT easier), I did it in 123D. I started with a sphere, cut off a quarter vertically, and to create the slopes I had to overlap cuboids to subtract off the extra parts (lazy way turned out to be the hard way here). Once that was done, I just mirrored the symbols on the cube over.
Also, when making the cube, please use supports, or bad things will happen to you and your dog...... EDIT 27/11: I printed these on the Makerbot Dual, and for some reason black ABS works much better than, say, white ABS. Something to do with expanding just after extrusion..

author: greeblin

description.text:
Groove mount using FSR (Force Sensing Resistor) for automatic bed leveling.
Rather than placing FSRs under the bed as originally proposed (http://reprap.org/wiki/FSR), I decided to put FSRs on the groove mount. Two FSRs are placed between the two parts of the groove mount.
This method allows to probe with lower pressure on the hot-end and can be used with any bed (even heated beds).
I use springs to keep both lower and upper parts together and fasten them to the effector, which protects the nozzle against crashes.
A demo video on my kossel:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wzcnmsPo-1o

Put two FSRs on the bottom part in the holes provided for this purpose (I used epoxy glue). Assemble with the top part and fasten to the platform with springs (to protect the nozzle agains crashs on the bed).
The FSRs must be connected in parallel to an analog PIN.
You can use it with the fsr branch of Johann C. Rocholl's Marlin firmware https://github.com/jcrocholl/Marlin/tree/fsr or with my fork:
https://github.com/Edlep/Marlin

comments.author: Timelord83

comments.text: I love this idea, but I'm a bit unfamiliar in how this works mechanically.  It looks like the "bottom" piece is rigid and attached to your end effector, and the 'top' is just pushed down on the FSR via springs?  And the impact of the nozzle touching the bed is enough to trigger the FSRs?
comments.author: eddieparker

comments.text:
Hi,
Actually, the bottom part is not fixed but just maintained on the effector by the top part (which is effectively pushed down on it via spings). The nozzle has a rigid link to the bottom part. The bottom part is pulled up (against the top one) when the nozzle is touching the bed, which raises the pressure measured by the FSR (between the two parts).
comments.author: eddieparker

comments.text: OK, so that makes sense - but how do you bind the hot end to your "bottom" part?  It looks like you have grooves in there, but I'm unsure how you secure the hot end to the effector.
comments.author: edlep

comments.text: Oh; maybe I see in your diagram - you actually have two screws that go into the holes on the side, holding the hot end by the groove itself... Is that right?  On another note, do you notice your prints coming out fine?  I worry that having any amount of flexibility in the hot end will cause my parts to not come out reliably.
comments.author: eddieparker

comments.text:
Yes, the hot end is blocked with two lateral screws.
No problem with the quality of the prints (even with high travel speeds).

author: middelweerd

description.text:
Spool roller with no bearings needed.
2.5mm shaft is required. In this build i used 2.5mm carbon fiber rod.
Maximum accomodable spool width is105mm.

Print List:
2 x Halter2-a
2 x Halter3-b
8 x makara Prepare :
2 x 123mm shaft rod (2.5mm dia) Construction:
  • With your preferred way of joining parts get 2 pieces of makara to form a wheel just like in the pictures. You will end up with 4 wheels.
  • Put each shaft rod through 2 wheels.
  • Attach rods to holes on halter2 pieces.
  • Slide halter2 side panels to halter3 notches to form a rectangular frame.
  • Adjust the wheel distance and put your filament spool on the wheels.
    • (optional)
  • Fix your roller to a board using screw holes.
  • Put some vibration dampening sponges on bottom surface.

These are housings for Z-Axis limit switches using TLE4905L magnetic hall-sensors, plus mounts for the magnets.
Since we didn't have much space to mount mechanical endswitches on our CNC-Mill, I decided to use hall sensors.
The sensors come as three legged PG-SSO-3-2
( Plastic Single Small Outline Packages ) and one needs a way to connect a cable and mount them somehow.
The magnets are 8x1mm neodyme magnets, so this works only for machines cutting non magnetic materials.
I installed the sensors, soldered the cables and used 2-component glue to fix and encapsulate the sensor (to hold everything in place while applying the glue, I used capton tape)
I printed this with PLA, since the part gets bended quite a bit when mounted, watch out for your part placment.

author: hudelotphilippe

title: Line Coil Hook
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a small hook designed to be used to hold coils of line (boat speak for rope). We have some similar devices on our sailboat, but they don't work too well, so I designed these.

First, Print the part on a 3d printer (or machine it on a 3-axis mill)
Note: if 3D printing, use a strong print material (i.e. ABS Plastic) with SOLID infill! this is very important, as the part will be bearing the weight of the line you are tying. Second, Bolt the hook (though the 1/4 inch hole in the center, the hole is chamfered to allow a flush bolt to fit nicely) where you want to hang your coil of line. Third, tie a small (1/8 inch or smaller) diameter string/small line to the loop at the bottom of the hook, the length of this line will depend on the size of the coil you wish to hang. The small line must pass through the center of the coil of large line, then back up to the hook at the top of the part, where a bowline (loop knot) should be tied to aid in quick hanging and removal of the large line. Unfortunately, as of yet, I do not have a 3D printer, or access to a 3-axis mill, so I can't post a picture detailing how to hang a line off this device, but if someone can see what i'm talking about and can make a couple, please post pictures and I'll tell you if you got it right! I've added an MS paint drawing that attempts to illustrate how to use the part, in the picture, the red is the part, blue is the small line, and green is the coil of line to be hung. I will be printing some of these off once I have access to the correct tools :-) Attached are the STL files and Autodesk Inventor part files for both a single unit, and a 10-unit set (and soon a 26 unit set designed to use the build platform space as efficiently as possible)

title: S3D profiles for the Replicator R2X

description.text:
These will heat up both left and right, or just left, or just right.
It will prime both, just left or just right depending on what profile you choose.
I have 2 sets of profiles.
One for the stock HBP from the R2X and one for the bottleworks HBP.
For the profiles labeled both it will move the right extruder to the front right corner, then prime the nozzle and do a slow wipe to the left.
Then it will move the left extruder to the front left corner, then prime the nozzle and do a slow wipe to the right.
For the profiles labeled right, this will only heat up the right extruder and prime the right nozzle.
For the profiles labeled left, this will only heat up the left extruder and prime the right nozzle.
The only differences between the BW and R2X are the built space dimensions in the profile.
This is not final and still being worked on. I was not able to test for the stock HBP since I have a bottleworks HBP. But the slow wipe goes long enough to wipe onto the stock R2X HBP.
Video URL is:
http://www.youtube.com/attribution_link?a=SDsxG3v4GV0&u=/watch%3Fv%3D2xu90uM335k%26feature%3Dem-upload_owner
Or
http://youtu.be/2xu90uM335k

Unzip the file for your printer.
Open S3D
Add or edit a process
At the top right next to "Select Profile" click on import
Goto the directory you unzipped the files in and select the file you want to import.
Repeat import for each file to have all three files imported

author: Nestor9dw

description.text:
Hi all, I know there are many filament holders out there and I’ve just added yet another one with this post.  I wanted to create a simple yet flexible filament holder for my Felix 3.0 3D printer.  Some holders are too bulky or are inflexible when it come to the roll sizes that they can take.  My previous holder (before I designed this one) was quite adequate and has served me very well since I printed it off, however I’ve now got dual extrusion and needed something that could take two filament rolls easily.  The expanding and contracting mechanism in my design allows for various diameters of filament to be used.  The whole assembly is easily mounted on the side of the Felix Printer.  
Please leave feedback.  
Enjoy!  
Pozzy 2014

With Pictures here:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1I6zr4ejCKoDd9sDlGTQz-Yu01p5QzHxmmvXxBkYyR38/edit?usp=sharing Sub-assembly (2 nr Sub-assemblies are required for one filament roll): Hardware required (Vitamins):
3 nr 30mm M4 Cap Head Screws
9 nr M4 Washers
3 nr M4 Nyloc Nuts
3 nr M4 Nuts Printed Parts: Filament Holder C Plate v2.stl
Filament Holder S Plate v2.stl
Nut Holder v2.stl You will need 2 sets of the above to make 1 FIlament holder plus the framing kit below:
Framing Kit:
Hardware required (Vitamins):
M6 Threaded Rod ~200mm long
3 nr M6 Nuts
1 nr M6 Washer
1 nr M6 Wing nut
Printed Parts
Packer Nut.stl
Packer.stl

Assembly Parts Required - Roll Holder (x2):
Place a washer along each of the M4 Cap Head Screw
Place this assembly through the curved plate (make sure that the recessed centre piece is facing upwards) and the Cap Head Screws are at the bottom.
Place a M4 washer onto the screws
Then place the Y shaped section over the M4 screws (you may have to move the screws about but make sure they don’t fall out).
Now place another washer on each of the screws.
Now tighten the whole assembly up by using the Nyloc nuts (don’t tighten it too much, you need it slack enough to move freely).
The whole assembly is tightened into place by way of the the Printed Nut Holder which take at one end of it an M4 nut (3 required for each assembly). Parts Required - Framing Kit
Assembly
Parts Required:
Set 1nr M6 Nut into the frame of the Felix (tip place a blob of blu tack or similar into the frame first then let this nut rest on it, position the with tweezers).
Now thread the 200mm rod into this nut, until the end inside pushes against the far side of the slot.
Then place an M6 Washer along the rod resting against the outside of the Felix frame.
Now position the rod on the frame and when you are happy tighten the whole thing up by placing an M6 nut against the outside washer (you’ll have to spin this down the length of the rod).
Now cove this using the printed packer (making sure that the large hole in the spacer is used to cover the locking nut next to the frame).

Then the holders and the filament to be used are placed along the threaded rod.
Another spacer and captive nut is used to secure the filament roll along the rod.
Finally an M6 Wing nut is used to lock the roll into place on the bar.
It should look something like the above.
I hope you all like this design, I have also made a version that uses bearings on the inside of the roll holder, however I much prefer this simpler version that just rotates on the rod.
Pozzy 2014
